bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, December 14, 1875

div1.p: Reed expresses his anxiety for Emilie Lawrence's health. He reiterates his devotion to her.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie B. Lawrence, December 14, 1875
div1.p:
This morning
on awaking from my night's slum-
bers, the first thought that came
into my mind, my darling,
was of you- More than this-
In my dreams I was with you
and saw your dear, sweet
face again- Oh! that this had
been a reality- Really, my
sweet E. I was never so
anxious to be with you as
during these last few days-
That I might beg your forgive-
ness for my conduct, & that I
might be with you to comfort
you in your distress. I am
almost determined to ask for a leave & come,
at once, to Murfreesboro. If you are taken sick,
my own darling, do not neglect to write me
immediately, so that I may come, at once, & be
with you. Oh! what a joy it would be to ex-
ecute your slightest wish and to attend your
least desire, and should you be taken ill (which
I pray that God, in his mercy, will avert) you
will not deny me the only pleasure left me in this
world, of doing what I can to alleviate your
sickness. Write me, as often as you can, if only
a few words, telling me of your that you are
well, for I am almost crazy with anxiety-
I don't want my style of writing to make
you sad, my precious Emilie, or to arouse
your fears that you will be taken sick: on the
other hand, I am only desirous that you should
take every precaution to protect your health;
and cheerfulness of spirit & a quiet of mind,
as much as is possible under the present
circumstances of your distress, will do
more than anything else to preserve your health.
Give yourself not a moment's thought concer-
ning my entire faithfulness -- for I love you
with a purer love, a more steadfast love
than ever before- My error is before me & I
have confessed it & asked your forgiveness-
When I have received that, or whether I re-
ceive it, I shall bury the matter out of sight
& out of mind- No power on this earth, other
than your own command, can prevent you
from being my own, sweet, dearly, twice
dearly loved Emilie! To whom I give the de-
votion of my whole heart! whose happiness
I it is the one purpose of my life to promote!
div1.closer:
Adieu my sweet! God bless & keep you safe!
and believe me, ever, your fond & devoted Walter.
